Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Genetic and developmental changes associated with the evolution of a hummingbird-pollination floral syndrome
Award.AbstractNarration: Flowers exhibit a multitude of forms that are astounding to human observers, but critical to the reproductive success of plants, and much of floral diversity has been shaped by evolutionary interactions between flowers and pollinators. Evolutionary shifts from bee- to bird-pollinated flowers have occurred numerous times, and contributed significantly to flower diversity. Yet there are two central issues that remain largely unexplored. What are the genetic changes that allow for an evolutionary transition from bee- to bird-pollination floral syndrome? And do similar genetic changes explain the many independent transitions to flowers optimized for bird pollination? The genus Penstemon is one of a few flowering plant groups well suited to address these questions - bird pollination has evolved more than ten times independently, and many species are inter-fertile, allowing for a genetic approach to determine the genes responsible for a complex suite of floral traits associated with bird-pollination. This project will develop molecular genetic tools in two closely related bee- and bird-pollinated Penstemon species. Tools will include transgenic approaches, genome sequencing and genetic mapping that will allow the researchers to explore the genetic changes necessary for a transition from bee- to bird-pollination floral traits. These early insights into the genetics of a pollination system shift will establish the foundation for a novel, highly integrative approach involving evolutionary, ecological, genetic and developmental studies to determine processes that underlie the evolution of complex traits. This project will contribute to the training of a postdoctoral researcher and undergraduate students at the interface of plant evolutionary genetics and development, and provide individuals from the emerging generation of scientists with skills in applying next-generation sequencing technology to critical questions of trait evolution. Undergraduates will be recruited through nationally funded programs at the University of Kansas aimed at increasing participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of this NSF award we generated proof-of-concept data that the flowering plant genus, Penstemon, is excellently suited to determine the genetic basis for complex trait evolution. During this same period, multiple early-career scientists were trained and elementary school students practiced critical thinking while enhancing their knowledge of the role of plant-pollinator interactions in plant life-cycles. These activities directly address the NSF goals of advancing knowledge (Intellectual Merit) and benefitting society (Broader Impacts).

Intellectual Merit

Determining the genetic basis for differences in complex traits between closely related (or distantly related) species is a major challenge in developmental biology. With this award, we generated proof-of-concept data demonstrating that species in the flowering plant genus Penstemon are excellently suited to dissect the genetic basis for complex trait evolution. Penstemon neomexicanus and Penstemon barbatus are closely related species, but develop flowers that are extremely divergent—adapted to bee- and hummingbird-pollination, respectively. We identified regions of the genome that differ between the two species in ways that explain the developmental differences between the bee- and hummingbird-adapted flowers. Our results suggest that very few genetic changes are required for a shift from bee-adapted to hummingbird-adapted flowers, making feasible our future work aimed at identifying the exact genes underlying complex differences in flower form. Additionally, we generated a draft genome sequence for Penstemon barbatus, which will facilitate the future identification of gene variants that distinguish bee- from hummingbird-adapted Penstemon flowers. Our Penstemon genomic data extend resources available to the plant science community. 

 

Broader Impacts

This award provided training and professional development for one female postdoctoral researcher, one graduate student and three undergraduate students. All trainees have long-term career goals in research. This award supported the development of an outreach module that impacts elementary students' appreciation for plant-pollinator interactions in the plant life-cycle, and enhances critical thinking and problem-solving skills by exploring the relationships between flowers and pollinators. We engaged approximately seventy first graders and fifteen 5th graders in this module.
